Award.AwardTitle: Flow Cytometry and Molecular Multi-User Facility at BIOS
Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to fully characterize and understand both regional and global climate, as well as fundamental ocean processes and functions, scientists are required to collect a wealth of information. Certain questions, such as how the ocean responds to global climate change, can only be answered by in-depth analysis of data collected continuously over a significantly long period of time, also known as a time-series study. The Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS) (www.bios.edu), an independent U.S. not-for-profit organization and a Bermuda Registered Charity, is home to several of the longest running, open-ocean time-series research programs in the world (Hydrostation 'S', the Bermuda Atlantic Time Series (BATS) Program and the Ocean Flux Program (OFP)). Bermuda's unique geographic position in close proximity to the open ocean, combined with BIOS' oceanographic support infrastructure, provide an ideal venue for research initiatives that address pressing issues in the ocean sciences. The new Flow Cytometry and Molecular Multi-User Facility (FCMMF) at BIOS will provide access to basic molecular instrumentation, in-house flow cytometer (laser-based technology used in cell counting, cell sorting and biomarker detection) and devices to vertically sample the ocean. This project will expand the number of important questions that can be locally addressed, while reducing the cost and risk associated with shipping samples off-island for all users. The large number of visiting scientists and ongoing scientific collaborations with external scientists, many with NSF-supported research programs, means that the equipment provided by the FCMMF will have a far reaching impact on the research capacity of the marine sciences community as a whole. Importantly, the FCMMF will assist BIOS in meeting the increasing student demand for research training in cutting-edge techniques. The educational goal of BIOS is to immerse students in experiential learning through research in the ocean sciences. This can be a seminal change for many students whose institutions lack programs in marine science or the opportunity to conduct independent research. Education experiences at BIOS can influence decisions that determine STEM education and career trajectories, with students leaving better prepared to pursue professional careers and/or graduate programs.

This new facility includes field sampling equipment that will provide a mechanism to collect individuals of the planktonic community (nano to mesoplankton) in a vertically stratified way. The chosen dry lab equipment platforms are characterized by their versatility, easy use and low maintenance. The Flow Cytometer model will allow the analysis of particles from 50 nm to 200 Ã¬m in diameter, facilitating a wide spectrum of studies, from environmental microbial ecology to eukaryotic cell biology. The modularity capability of this unit will allow for future improvement and expansion if desired. The molecular component of the facility will allow basic analyses and also support sample preparation for next-generation sequencing. The FCMMF will benefit a wide range of research programs at BIOS, as well as those of visiting scientists. Paralleling the benefits to basic research, the FCMMF facility has been explicitly designed for use with student internships, current BIOS courses and the development of new courses, particularly a modern biological oceanography course. Since 2010, BIOS has hosted an average of 105 visiting scientists and over 750 students annually, most of them from US institutions. The FCMMF allows BIOS to provide scientists and students with the ability to address numerous and diverse biological questions. In addition to biological oceanography, this project will benefit a wide variety of research programs including genome structure and gene expression in marine invertebrates, larval longevity and gene flow in corals, temporal and spatial fine-scale characterization of open ocean microbial and eukaryotic communities, organismal response to ocean acidification, and the biological processes influencing ocean-atmosphere gas exchange of carbon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS) (www.bios.edu) is an independent U.S. not-for-profit organization that has a unique geographic position in close proximity to the open ocean, as well as one of the strongest oceanographic infrastructures worldwide. BIOS is home to several of the longest running, open-ocean time-series research programs in the world; these time-series programs collect and analyze data continuously over a significantly long period of time in order to address questions of critical societal importance, such as how the ocean responds to global climate change. The creation of a Flow Cytometry and Molecular Multi-User Facility (FCMMF) has allowed BIOS to build on the existing oceanographic infrastructure via the acquisition of equipment essential for modern biological oceanography research. The equipment expands research capabilities for collection and analysis of samples from the open ocean, allowing researchers to investigate changes occurring in the water column community and assessing their implication for ecosystem structure, species interactions, and biogeochemical cycles. The FCMMF will benefit a wide variety of additional research programs, however, including genome structure and gene expression in marine invertebrates, larval longevity and gene flow in corals, organismal response to ocean acidification, and the biological processes influencing ocean-atmosphere gas exchange of carbon. BIOS's educational goal is to immerse students in experiential learning through research in the ocean sciences, providing experiences that can influence STEM education and career trajectories. Because the FCMMF was designed for use by student interns and university course participants, it is helping BIOS to meet the increasing student demand for research training in cutting-edge techniques.

During the one-year duration of this award, the goal of acquiring equipment and ensuring that the FCMMF is available for shared-use by scientists and students was achieved. All instrumentation was ordered and received at BIOS within the anticipated timeframe and budget. The FCMMF is housed temporarily in a research lab, with shared-use access, until renovation of the permanent, designated laboratory is complete (projected for December 2016).

The new FCMMF includes field sampling equipment, received in mid-2016, designed for deployment from BIOS's research vessel for the collection of planktonic organisms from discrete depths in the open ocean, thereby allowing both researchers and students to pursue depth-related biological questions. Such "vertically stratified" sampling, using a multiple-net, mid-water (tucker) trawl and a large-volume water transfer system pump, is essential in understanding how organisms and species interact and respond to their environment. The field sampling equipment is scheduled to be used on research cruises starting in 2017. The new FCMMF's laboratory equipment includes a flow cytometer. This machine, through laser-based technology, allows scientists to rapidly count and sort cells and can be used for research ranging from environmental microbial ecology to the study of larger, multi-cellular organisms. Installation and calibration of the flow cytometer was completed in May 2016, as which time 2 BIOS scientists, 3 research specialists and 1 research technician were trained on the machine. The flow cytometer is now available to all users, including undergraduate students. A U.S. undergraduate student participating in BIOS's Fall Semester Program, for example, was trained to use the flow cytometer in order to conduct a research project to determine if feeding and clearance rates of the Bermuda mangrove oyster are affected by temperature. The FCMMF also provides access to instrumentation that allows for basic molecular analyses and supports sample preparation for next-generation sequencing. The shared-use molecular equipment arrived at BIOS in early summer 2016 and was available for immediate use. To date, the molecular equipment, including the NanoDrop spectrophotometer used to analyze and quantify DNA, has been used by BIOS resident scientists, 4 visiting scientists and 4 research interns.

In summary, the new FCMMF at BIOS has expanded the number of important research questions that can be addressed locally, while eliminating the need for all users to ship samples off-island, thereby reducing the associated cost and risk. The large number of visiting scientists and BIOS Faculty's ongoing scientific collaborations with external scientists, many with NSF-supported research programs, means that the equipment provided by the FCMMF will have a far-reaching impact on the research capacity of the marine sciences community as a whole. Although the FCMMF only became available in mid-2016, undergraduate research interns and course students have already received training on, and utilized, the Facility's equipment, thereby broadening BIOS's impact on the next generation of scientists.
